reviewText:
Who is Mike is a very short (<hour) horror/mystery Visual Novel that does many things right.

Pros:
*It features very nice art and interesting, suspenseful short story.
*There are multiple simple choices that branch the story in different ways, allowing you to reach different endings.
*The outcome (and even the premise) of the story depends on your choices.
*It's free, short, and doesn't overstay its welcome.

Cons:
*The choices and consequences are usually not very intuitive or clear, so the ending you get will probably be unexpected.
*Therefore, if you wish to see all endings, you will need to follow a guide.

If you've ever wondered what the hell is a visual novel, if you like short horror/mystery stories, or if you just have a free hour of your time - you should try it.

reviewText: Who is Mike is a decent mystery Visual Novel, with a hand full of endings. Who is Mike is pretty short, you can probably get most of the endings in an hour. reviewText: A great, enticing little visual novel with many different chilling endings. Who is Mike? features an interesting little story of two people named Mike Jansen who look the same, and think the same, trying to figure out who is real, and who is not, with the help of their girlfriend. It shines in the music department, great pieces really setting the scene for each outcome, the writing ranges from humourous to dramatic and makes you think real deep about what to say next. Long story short, it's a great tale and I really recommend it to anyone who wants a good mystery. Very great read.

reviewText:
Interesting story and setting at first. But since there are almost no branching storylines (except for 2 endings), the game becomes repetitive very fast.

Most of the answers are 'tell a lie' or 'tell the truth', it would've been more interesting to have some variation to them.
This also makes it difficult to remember which question you're answering while in skip mode.

Achievements would be helpful to keep track of which endings you've already found.

reviewText:
I am Mike.

So is he.

We are standing in a room, trying to figure out if I am me or if he is. My girlfriend is here as well. We have to try and convince her that we are the real Mike.

If we guess wrong, I die. If we guess wrong, he dies. If we guess wrong, Sarah dies.

If I am lucky, perhaps Mike can live. Perhaps Sarah can live.

And if I or he are not Mike, then what is he or I?

reviewText:
TL;DR: It's a bit repetitive, but still good.
My biggest problem with this one involves the endings, but I'll keep this review as spoiler-free as possible. Getting to them is a pain on its own: Which ending you get depends on how you answer a short series of questions. This would usually be alright, if the paths to each ending weren't so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ random. Choosing between liking dogs or hyenas can completely change the entire plot of the game, and since there's no ramifications between questions, you don't get any indication of which ending you're headed towards, until it's already too late to turn back. If you refuse to use a walkthrough, be prepared for a ton of save-scumming, and just randomly checking every single possible combination of answers until you find the 6-7 endings missing from your list.
I don't really like the way that every single route completely contradicts eachother either, but that's really more of a matter of personal taste.

All that said, the game is alright. The art, despite having a few slips here and there, is pretty good, and the narrative can create some pretty good tension in important scenes. The music, as simple as it is, is pretty eerie, and really helps the atmosphere. And the story really compels you to keep reading, since there's no way of knowing what you're about to find. Definitely pretty good for a free to play game.

As frustrating as getting every single ending can be sometimes, I had fun with this one. Definitely recommended if you have an hour or two to kill.

reviewText:
This is a spoiler-free review.

Who Is Mike is a very enjoyable way to pass an hour or so.

Pros:

- Great art, especially for a free game.
- Good writing, moreso than in many of the indie VNs I've played. It can get repetitive when the protagonist is angsting, but in a believable way.
- Unusual plot that keeps you guessing until the last minute.
- Free.

Cons:

- Short. Which is fine, especially for a free game, but if you like your VNs long with many branches, this is not one of them.
- Lack of variety in player choices. For most of the game, you'll be faced with the same decision again and again in slightly different contexts.
- Non-intuitive branches. Maybe it's just me, but it took a lot of trial and error, followed by reluctant use of a guide, to figure out how to get all the endings that branch off from the main section of the game.
- Inconsistent storyline. This is the one truly bad thing about this game - instead of the endings gradually giving you more and more bits of the puzzle, like in a good mystery VN, different endings reveal that you were playing different scenarios all along. It's a bit like a murder mystery where the the murderer turns out to be a different person depending on the choices you make during your investigation, even though the clues are all the same each time.

In the end, I definitely recommend it. It is a distinct and memorable experience that costs no money and not too much of your time.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've managed to get all but one ending for Who is Mike so there are spoilers ahead.

You play as Mike, an ordinary guy who suddenly wakes up in his living room with a bit of amnesia from possibly a few hours ago. The only other person in the room with you is none other than yourself. The question is are you the real Mike?

First of all, the story line is intriguing: the tension between both Mikes and Sarah (depending on one of the choices you make) works really well. One of the reasons why it succeeds in this is the music. It's disonant yet simplistic sound creates great tension in it's darkened setting. The characters are interesting and their dialogue is enough to gauge their personalities. The artwork is absolutely beautiful and matches the grittiness to this tale.

However, the story itself is very short (but it can be shorter depending on your choices) and for a visual novel, you don't get to interact that much in terms of choosing how to answer or make your decision. Speaking of decisions, it lets itself down a little when you make some important choices.  The fake in the story is some kind of life draining demon, who can shape-shift into their victims and pretty much steal their identity. Depending on how you play the game, you could either die by leaving the house and inadvertedly let the demon drain your soul/life force, get shot by Sarah (Mike's girlfriend) when attacking the 'Fake Mike' or get stabbed by the demon when they transform into Sarah (only if you decide not shoot her). Focusing on the first two deaths, you as the player would either be the real Mike or the fake Mike, but it depends on how you respond to the questions Sarah asks both Mikes. You wonder who's persective you were playing from in the first place once you obtain the endings, where both Mikes end up in a fist fight. I was certinly confused when I played through again.

Saying that, if you're looking for a visual novel with a good storyline where you can discuss your theories, and what's going on and you want to feel a lot of tension between characters, this game will satisfy those needs. Just over look what I said in the spoiler part and you should be fine.

I give this game 7/10 .

reviewText:
A very compelling who-done-it with a supernatural twist. When it comes to visual novels, the dialog between characters can make or break the game. If the dialog is too forced or cheesy it'll completely break the immersion, however, 'who is mike' strikes the right cadence between lightheartedness and dead seriousness all the time without breaking that very important immersion.

The subject is relate-able and a bit creepy to me because on a personal level I've had a family member taken away by mental illness, it's scary, they end up a shell of themselves that you don't know anymore but 'who is mike' is a bit different. You gain consciousness only to find yourself standing face to face with you. Both of you insist to be the real thing but one is pretending, and for sinister reasons. Great original story.

Let's talk about the sound, the cues are spot on and really help drive the emotion of the game. While the loops could be managed better (a bit jarring when a track restarts) the pieces chosen are perfect to cultivate the fear, foreboding, or relief the developer wants the player to feel.

There aren't many different backdrops or character models but given the length of the game it suffices. If there is one thing I'd like to change about the game is to have the character text actually originate in speech bubbles from the characters speaking. Having to read the text at the bottom all the time really does detract from the overall 'visual novel' element of such games. The dialog would more powerful if you can see the face of the person as they speak it.

Is this free game worth 2 hours of your time? Yes! I wholeheartedly recommend playing it, but keep in mind it's not really for unsupervised children (strong language).

If you want to hear me narrate 15 minutes of the game feel free to watch my first time playing it below (minor spoilers):
https://youtu.be/0PAZw8sAYT8

reviewText: Depending on how fast you can read and click your mouse button, playing this game through to one of its many conclusions can take as little as fifteen minutes.  Now, obviously, this is more than acceptable for a free game, so unlike many an arsewipe out there in Steamland, I'm not going to use this game's brevity as cause to condemn it.  Nor am I going to argue that it's not by-and-largely well-written, and reasonably entertaining for what it is.  Hell, it's even a mite bit intriguing, especially near the beginning.  But the content of the story is highly unlikely to blow your socks off unless you were either cloned last week, and/or have never read a sci-fi short story or watched an episode of The Twilight Zone (any series or era) in your life.  It's cool.  It's nice.  It's probably even worth fifteen minutes to a couple of hours of your time, if you're the type who's determined to see each and every ending.\n\nMe...I'm good for now, though there's every chance I may give it another burl sometime between now and death.  Recommended, if only by virtue of its free-ness and undeniably solid quality.  Unless you don't like reading.  Though having said that, enough of you seem to enjoy those mindless clicker" games
recommended: it may even have some appeal to that most perplexing of target audiences
hoursPlayed: since you really will get to click your left mouse button an awful lot between the start and end of the game.\n\nVerdict: 6.5/10."

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This is a review of a single, free work, not an endorsement of any future works of this developer. I know nothing about the developer and chose to take artistic merit into account becuase this game was made for its own sake and not for profit.

This story/game is pretty great. It's subtle and was obviously well thought-out (but it's also a bit arbitrary-seeming if you are the type that doesn't believe in telling small lies to your lover).

The variations/endings are not hard to sniff out if you give it 1-3 hours of your time. What are you? What defines a person? Is a person that's exactly the same as you, still you? Rare is the story where you find yourself as a protagonist *and* antagonist in turns.

Even if you're not the type of gamer to like Visual Novels, give this one a chance if you're a fan of mystery and/or horror genres.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Product received for free

This visual novel was short among the ones I've played, but nonetheless it was an interesting experience.

Who Is Mike is nothing all too complex, though it can be fairly difficult to figure out the choices meant to lead you to a specific ending. You really can figure it out with a few tries, and it only takes about five minutes to get to the main ending, and around a minute for the shortest. Not a challenge for any seasoned visual novelist, I can assure you, but it can be fairly confusing at times.

Art was so-so as far as I can see. Slightly better than what you might see in any other plain game, but nothing special. Pretty pixelated for a game of this type, too, but I'm sure that was on purpose. Story was original by my standards, which, though my standards are not very high, I can at least pick it out among the other stories that attempted to center around clones.
Soundtrack was better than expected, building the atmosphere in a way that wouldn't be possible had there been none at all. However, I don't feel it stood out in any other ways, and thus faded into the background at most points. Still, it deserves a mention.

It really didn't take me too long to get through this. That's probably a good thing, as I tend not to stick with anything that doesn't offer achievements. That's kind of my selling point, I guess. But achievements or no, I'd give this a whirl. What's there to lose?

Start: This is a great free visual novel that I suppose you should spend some of your time reading. Having no achievements make it boring, but the multiple endings make it someone easy to keep track off. (Go on Youtube or search a Guide to see if someone got all the endings)

Pros:
- Great Characters (You,The other mike, your girlfriend named Sarah)
- Music is awesome and feels nice. While the same tone, it feels fresh.
- Different endings cause you to replay
- You can skip if you choose and the options give you how fast you want to skip,nice little slider. (Should of put Slow,Medium or Fast but this is still fine)

Cons:
- Music was a bit to loud at some parts (No headphones gave my right here a shock at 100% volume)
- Extras are really just art scenes from the novel and don't show what choices you really did
- No achievements make it boring with all these choices.

End: Great game. I would give it all of your time and waste some time on it. (Not wasted time if you enjoy it :3)

the art is great as well- however dont expect much of it, because most of the story takes place in one room. It did'nt matter much to me though, because I was so invested in the dialog.

I also loved the length of the game, it took my friends and I about 50 minutes to get the first ending, which is perfect for the game, its not rushed or too drawn out.

over all, I'd give this game a 9/10

+ I really enjoyed the story, it was a nice twist.
+ Multiple endings.
+ It's free, but it's actually better than most Visual Novels that cost money.


+/- It's actually pretty short, I'm kind of hoping for a sequel" of some sort!"

A very interesting Visual Novel that any fan of the genre should play. A bit dissapointed at the length and that it took a lot of trial and error to get all endings but i can't whine too much when it's free for anyone to play. Overall it's great though and anyone should give it a go.

This game is, in my opinion, pretty freakin' cool. An ending tracker would be a little nice, but aside from that (and being longer, but, come on, it's a free game) I can't think of anything to improve.

It has a compelling story that requires you to think, and regardless of which path is chosen there is always something a little different, so it doesn't feel boring to replay for the different endings. The story itself is well written in both a linguistic and literary sense.

The art is very well drawn, and stylistically fits with the writing, as does the music.

I'm definitely going to be watching the devs and right now, I think I'm going to go and see about playing their other game, Cupid.

reviewText: It's free and it's short. The story's decently interesting even if there's not a lot really explained in the end. Can't say much else without spoiling stuff, though, but there were some interesting surprises.

Its a bit short, but there are a bunch of different endings to find.

Its free, and it will entertain you for about an hour (if you go for all endings), so I can't complain.

The art and music are nice, for sure, but what I really liked was the writing. I got a sense of the characters and felt connected to them in a very short time, which really made some of the decisions heavy. Sure, it isn't long, but I think it is very well executed for something so short.

I have played many VN's and I have not often played a bad one that was created via Ren'py. This is a well put together VN with many different outcomes and paths. The game itself is far beyond your regulay VN's created by amateurs. I would dare say that if the game expands, in some time, it could take on Katawa Shoujo in terms of entertainment. You can take the game on a serious level, or you can clown areound with your friends on the events of the game, but either way you will be enjoying yourself. I do wish that it was a bit longer, but I can understand its length for being a new game. This game should be at least five dollars, because it is fantastic. I'm hoping, as well as looking foward to, this game's sequel. 5+Stars

reviewText:
Fairly short with atleast 1 hour of gameplay if you intend to get all 9 endings.
The CG for the game is well done and the music used fits the atmosphere pretty damn well.
The dialogue is great, when it's funny it's funny, when it's serious it's it's serious, when its threatening it's threatening. You get the point.

The endings are not all related and (Idk whether this is a spoiler or not)  there is not really any fixed imposter  which gives quite abit of replayability to view the other endings.
Most of them involve death or are just plain depressing, either that or they pull a M Night Shamalan grade plot twist.
I think there was probably only one ending where everything was settled peacefully".

Overall 8/10
No issues with the game
date: short and sweet and completely free.\n\nWish they had some kind of secret ending though"

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game, short, simple although,

-spoiler warning-
I found the endings didn't make sense, if you unlock all endings there will be ones where 'you' the character are the evil fake mike but in others the purple jumpered mike is the evil one.

This problem is shown again when theres a option to shoot Sarah outside the bedroom door. I originally shot Sarah and it was apparently the innocent version but if i waited to ask a question, this 'innocent' Sarah suddenly becomes the evil one.

Point is, it feels like plot holes were created to artifically create more endings without anymore real story being added.
-end of spoilers-

Ultimately, the music added to the tension in the game and the plot was pretty niche and interesting. For a free game, no complaints. Was a fun way to spend 1-hour.

reviewText:
There's not enough psychological visual novels in this world. It's my favourite type of game and it's always a shame when I start to run cold on new titles. I found this one for free and the premise instantly hooked me and I'm glad i played this one.

The description explains everything you need to know about the plot, minus spoilers, so I will not discuss it.

First, the presentation is great, especially for a free title. I love the design of both characters and they are well-drawn. They also have several poses and some scene-specific drawings.

Second, the dialogue is fantastic. The dialogue made me feel like I got to know both characters in such a small length of time and no dialogue felt out-of-character or unrealistic for the situation.

Thirdly, the game has nine endings that all got me interested and asking questions. I'll admit I had to look up a guide to find endings 6-8.

Fourth, I would have paid money for this honestly. I know it's short (it took me an hour to get all the endings), but I felt my time was well-spent and I would come back just to re-experience it and to show a friend.

So yes, get it. It is free and more than worth your time if you are into psychological visual novels.
Suspenseful, fun, and free!  There's a lot left unanswered; I feel like this could be the prologue to a much longer game.
11/10 would let their weenie feel good again

Its put together very well and its crazy how quickly the atmosphere changed! One second cracking jokes about your brother and gossiping about a model and the next commiting cold blooded murder!!! tldr;big on art,atmosphere, and endings , short on time and some dialogue. Must play if you enjoy danganronpa and crime interogation shows.

Well, I'd have to say the concept is very interesting. I never played a visual novel before so I didn't know what exactly to expect.
The gameplay is simple, throughout the game you will have to make choices at certain points. You can only choose from two different options. In the end, this effects your outcome and you can get up to over 9 different endings (I think.) Based on your choices a lot of interesting twists could happen and some I was a little bit suprised.
A bonus of this game is whenever you want to try to get a different ending there is a 'Skip' button that would allow you to fly through the story without having to read the plot again. Another thing that I liked is that there is some humor here and there that was great.
With the game being a bit short I still enjoyed the game a lot. If you like a bit of mystery and choice making then this would be a great game to try out.
Intriguing, Thought-Provoking Thriller. Worth the quick playthrough.

Suspenseful, fun, and free!  There's a lot left unanswered; I feel like this could be the prologue to a much longer game.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nA short, fairly decent way to chew up a few spare minutes. At the low-low cost of 'Free' it definitely doesn't hurt to download and give this VN a spin. By not knowing who's real and who's not, the game does a good job of simulating the real confusion of encountering a duplicate. However, the only real gameplay is player agency and making choices, and it's never clear what the results of choices are going to be. Ends up being more random than anything else.
Has a interesting plot,  and the character design is good. I enjoyed the game even though it's kinda short.
I thinks it's a great game, after having gotten all of the endings. If you're interested in this I think you should give it a go! (`0`)/////////////////////////////

Definitely recommend this game to a fan of visual novels, or just to fans of good stories in general. To get the best possible experience, you may have to use a walkthrough to suss out what to do, but it is very rewarding when you do get the ending you want. 7/10

This is sincerely one of THE best games I have ever played. I've been going through a lot of terrible demos and free games lately and I am SO  glad I've found this one. It's deep, it makes you think, it knows exactly when and how to throw in humor. The writing and concept are superb and the art is gorgeous. There is literally NOTHING I can think of that is bad about this game. As of this very moment, I've only played through to one ending. And I'm about to willing spend the time when I should be sleeping finding and playing through to all the others. Fervent, you are quite probably a god among Indie developers.
this game is awesome

A compelling horror/mystery visual novel. Your protagonist and his double with almost his same memories, confront each other in his living room, accusing each other of invading his house. Like the who's the imposter?" TV trope turned into a mystery thriller.\n\nGetting all nine endings took me under two hours
date: but they were well spent. And it's free

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nneat endings if you can find them all haha :P who is mike>:)
A bit repetitive, but its still pretty good ^-^

Mike is an ordinary guy who one day finds himself talking to a doppelganger - a being who looks, talks & walks like him... or at least, almost :).

I say almost, because Mike's got a girlfriend (Sarah) who happens to have a very keen eye (she is a cop after all), and is capable of sniffing out the slightest of lies, spun by her potentially soon-to-be husband.

The story starts with one version of Mike, bumping into & answering to what looks like another version of himself (in what appears to be a living room).

From this point onwards, the player is given the choice to either proceed truthfully (or deceivingly) while being subjected to a series of personal questions by none other than the fierce & feisty girlfriend Sarah.

There's a total of 9 endings (where you end up being the real mike or an impostor, who gets to stay, leave, live or even die!), depending on the answers given.

---

This is an interesting VN. Way too short however! Even though I proceeded slowly & cautiously, I managed to complete the game the first time within 50 minutes of playtime.

It started out really well and then poof. Before I knew it, it was over. Too bad!

Doesn't take long to install though, so it's suitable for anyone who's new to VNs and would like to get a taste of the genre, without needing to spend a penny or deal with downloadable content to enjoy the story.

The art, sound effects and music are of the exact same quality as applied in CUPID" (another project from the developers).

Just as effective though!

If you like the look
date: feel and delivery style of "Who Is Mike?" then
recommended:
there's a big probability you would like "CUPID" as well.

Both contained great music!

Go ahead and see for yourself! :)"
